session_history.content: What parallel degree should I use for TerraData Schema Transfer Utility?

To determine the appropriate parallel degree for the TerraData Schema Transfer Utility, it's essential to have specific information about your environment, including system specifications, network bandwidth, schema size and complexity, resource usage, and testing results.

Key Observations

  • The optimal parallel degree depends on factors such as CPU, memory, I/O bandwidth, Teradata version, and network bandwidth between source and target systems.
  • Schema size and complexity, including the number of tables, views, macros, and their sizes, influence the ideal parallel degree.
  • Monitoring resource utilization on both source and target systems during test transfers is crucial for finding the right balance.
  • Experimenting with different parallel degrees and analyzing transfer time, CPU utilization, and I/O wait times is recommended for optimization.
Collateral Report for: Ad-hoc Query

No user question provided.

I am unable to provide guidance on the parallel degree for the TerraData Schema Transfer Utility because no relevant data was provided. To provide accurate guidance, I would need information about your specific environment, including:

  • Source and Target Teradata System Specifications: CPU, memory, I/O bandwidth, and Teradata version.
  • Network Bandwidth: The bandwidth between the source and target Teradata systems.
  • Schema Size and Complexity: The number of tables, views, macros, and other database objects being transferred, as well as the size of the largest tables.
  • Resource Usage Monitoring: Information on current resource utilization on both the source and target systems during a test transfer.
  • Testing Results: Results from previous schema transfer attempts with different parallel degrees, including transfer time, CPU utilization, and I/O wait times.

Without this information, it's impossible to recommend an optimal parallel degree. Using too high a degree of parallelism can exhaust system resources, leading to performance degradation and potential instability. Using too low a degree of parallelism can result in unacceptably long transfer times.

Data: Result for TDA_FinalReport
